What is the problem the user is experien:
From GoHealth: Within the checkpoint, all the columns in the list of learners are not sortable. We want to keep track of which learner is pending approval to make sure our checkpoint approvers are approving in a timely manner. An easy way for me to do that would be to sort the learners based on the status of their checkpoint. Then, I am able to get a headcount of who is waiting for approval all at once instead of weeding through the hundreds of learners within the checkpoint. Another reason for columns to be sortable would be so we could see how many learners each approver has approved or rejected. Again, this would be another way we can easily track approvers’ performance.  Ideally, we want all this information in a report that can easily be pulled, but this could be an easy fix before we can get the report we want.

The reports that we can pull do not have all the information we need. Reports that can be exported from either a checkpoint or the insights section, and they do not have the date the checkpoint was approved nor the name/ID of the approver. We need this information to document for our records when certificates were approved in the checkpoint. Also, when pulling the report, the learner’s status is not as defined as it could be. On the list of leaners section, it shows the agent’s progress as open, completed, pending approval, and retry. We would really like to see this in the report as well. The progress status we really need is the retry status. The only way to find out which agents were denied approval is if you comb through the long list of learners in the checkpoint or if you pull a separate report in insights that only shows agents who “must retake” the checkpoint. BUT when you export this report within the deep dive, there is no status distinction between those who are overdue because they have not submitted for approval and those who are overdue because they were denied approval (“must retake”). This is time consuming because the filter options in the enrollment status section of the deep dive do not align with how that enrollment status is defined in the report that is pulled.
Why would fixing this problem be valuabl: They are implementing and leaning heavily on the checkpoint feature in Bridge. Checkpoints are now used to track certifications their employees need to have in order to be appointed and sell with an insurance carrier. They believe Bridge is a great place to document this information and somewhere their Licensing Team can easily access these certificates and approve them, but they are having trouble pulling reports from both the checkpoint itself and the deep dive feature in Insights.

What is the problem the user is experien:
Email from customer:
"The pain point would be in the lack of reporting for account admin/admins in a user friendly U/I solution. We should not be expected to look at the data dump reports. We know the data exists so why not make it visually and easier for a manager/account admin/admin to use?

Our company goal is to give each employee a quarterly goal of 10 hours of coursework OR 40 hours annually. To try to achieve reporting on this is manual and gruesome. Therefore, my idea is to build a report based on the data that is already being recorded in the data dump.

Expectation:

Admins should expect to be able to look up any user within a timeframe to see how many hours completed for all courses, live programs, and all programs. Nice to have: users (end users) will be able to see their total time allocated to completed coursework on their completed learning dashboard based on a date range they can look at to ensure there are within their goal.  

Here would be the conditions:

By user, need a way to filter a time period of X to X (January 1 – January 31) up to a 18 month time frame (that way we reduce the amount of load pulling old data).
Need to pull in courses within the date timeframe given, that shows completed only (exclude in progress) for courses, live programs and programs the user has taken.
I need the report to pull user name, time in course/program, and duration of course/program (since we might use this instead if it’s more accurate) for only completed courses. 

Outcome:
 
If a user goes into Insights OR goes into user profiles one-by-one, they should be able to go to a user profile and pull up how many hours of coursework, live program, or program work that has been completed (exclude in progress) within a date time frame given by the user (up to 18 months at minimum)."
Why would fixing this problem be valuabl: This would give a significant amount of time back to admins who are having to compile multiple reports from our data dump for a large number of users.

What is the problem the user is experien:
We have several courses that recur annually. The current expire/re-enroll tool is based on the last time the learner completed the course. For example, if a training was assigned company-wide on June 1 and employees have 30 days to complete, then the next year, it will assign for those employees on different dates depending on when they completed. We typically allow 30 days so most of them will get a redeployment sometime in May or June to keep them in compliance. If someone is out on FMLA leave or a new employee starts in say, September, those people are then off-cycle. Because of the rolling deployment based on the completion date, everyone else also starts to be staggered. Eventually, everyone is different. 

This makes it difficult to monitor when courses will be deployed, which prevents us from staggering them so that some employees don't get overburdened at any one time. It also makes pushing updates to these courses difficult because it seems like someone is always actively enrolled in the courses.

What we would really like is the ability to say, "Training X is always due on June 30" instead of just scheduling them all for 30 day completion from the time of enrollment.
Why would fixing this problem be valuabl: This would help companies maintain compliance and not require authors/admins to re-create courses with a unique enrollment date, which makes completion tracking through the years a challenge
